newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore leader optimistic on economic prospects.
newsitem.headline: Singapore leader optimistic on economic prospects.

text.p: Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said on Friday the outlook for the Singapore economy in 1997 was generally optimistic with growth momentum picking up.

Goh told an industry function that weak growth in the first quarter of the year, in which the economy grew by 3.8 percent year-on-year, was partly due to a sluggish manufacturing sector and slower trading activities.
"The outlook for the remainder of 1997 is generally optimistic," he said.
"Economic growth in our major export markets is expected to remain robust."
"Domestically, while year-on-year growth in the first quarter was weak, growth momentum is picking up," Goh said.
He said quarter-to-quarter growth figures had turned positive since the last quarter of 1996 and industrialists were generally more optimistic about business conditions for the next six months.

"The manufacturing sector is expected to recover in line with the pick up in global electronics demand while the chemicals industry (should) benefit from additional capacity coming on stream," he said.
Goh repeated the government's previously stated growth forecast for 1997 of five to seven percent.
Singapore is heavily dependent on the electronics sector, which accounts for about half of industrial output and almost 60 percent of its non-oil exports.

The economy was hit hard last year by a slowdown in the global electronics industry, with overall growth slipping to seven percent from 8.8 percent in 1995 and double digit growth the preceeding two years.
Goh said Singapore faced keener competition from developing countries and that the economy had to be increasingly innovative to stay ahead.
"To keep abreast of the competition, we must be prepared to innovate ahead of others and create new market niches for ourselves where we can add more value and command a premium," he said.
Goh said he had asked the Ministry of Trade and Industry to convene an economic committee to study Singapore's competitiveness.
The committee would assess strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats facing the economy and recommend strategies and policies to ensure it stays competitive.
"My concern is not over our current competitiveness. It is whether we can compete for the long term," he said.
